title: Between 1 July 2018 and 30 June 2019, will an armed group from South Sudan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in South Sudan?
preds: According to the BBC: "South Sudan war: The handshake that may end a recurring nightmare" https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-45511352

https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2018/country-chapters/south-sudan
/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-14019202 Looking at a timeline of the events that have taken place in South Sudan for the past couple of years, the likelihood that such a mass killing campaign occurring seems relatively low. At this moment in the conflict, there are more people being displaced, but looking at recent events in the conflict, the chance of mass killing with that high of a body count to occur seems relatively low.
Violence will not stop until enough autonomy is granted to tribes in the region.

New treaties are in place all around, which in this part of the world means the conflict is about to start. Left un-covered in the texts of the treaties is the status and fate of the border states and demarcation of the joint oil fields. Remember one controls the oil and the other controls market access through pipelines etc. THey've been batting a thousand on failed peace treaties so I'm holding above consensus. A little.
Beause it is a very tenuous accord between factions... https://allafrica.com/stories/201808170689.html

It's just a guess after researching the recent civil war events in South Sudan. There are multiple variables to consider but I believe all those complicated variables will forstall any formal or systemized planned campaign to slaughter a lot of people. In addition, the world is watching and world human rights investigators have a way of  disrupting the lives of criminals at a time long after they thought they got away with their crimes.

My answer is yes. I think if it happens anywhere it South Sudan (SS) is most likely. 
Now let's get down into why.  First, there is political instability, as of last night, the Parliament voted to extend the president's election until 2021 [1] (sources are listed below). This matters because, this is the same regime where peace deals have been bartered and broken [2].  Also, "likely to undermine peace talks as opposition groups have said the change would be illegal." is quoted in the same article.  "should be declared as a rogue regime,” Mabior Garang de Mabior, spokesman of Machar’s rebel group," On to the second part, it's happening very recently [3]. There are reports that between April and May, 232 Civilians were killed  and 120 women/girls were gang raped by an army of soldiers and it is likely to be higher. But why does this happen?  Quoted in the same article, the targets were in "targeted opposition-controlled villages in the north of the country in April and May, government troops and allied militias". Also the fighting increases when people are fighting.  The next part, it is the lean season.  About half the country is malnourished [4][5].  There are only a couple of rebel groups in South Sudan. It's not a far jump to make that one group is blaming the other group for taking all the food. So what is one (morbid) solution to that problem (or justification), kill people who are opposing so we can all survive. Kind of like Thanos.  1.
